questions.question: Which of the following best describes a Use Case Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. Graphical representation of system functionality
questions.option_c: C. Shows interaction between system and external entities
questions.option_d: D. Used only in coding phase
questions.explanation: A Use Case Diagram graphically represents the functional behavior of a system from a user's perspective.

questions.question: Which of the following is a basic component of a Use Case Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. Actors
questions.explanation: Actors represent external entities or roles that interact with the system, making them a core component of Use Case Diagrams.

questions.question: Which statement correctly defines a System Boundary?
questions.option_a: A. Separates system from external environment
questions.option_c: C. Represents the flow of data
questions.explanation: The system boundary defines the scope of the system by visually separating internal processes from external actors.

questions.question: What do Actors represent in Use Case Diagrams?
questions.option_a: A. Roles interacting with the system
questions.explanation: Actors represent external roles (users or systems) that interact with the system to achieve goals.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an actor in a Hotel Management System?
questions.option_a: A. Guest
questions.explanation: Guests are external users who interact directly with the system, thus representing a valid actor.

questions.question: Which question helps identify use cases for an actor?
questions.option_a: A. What tasks does the actor perform?
questions.option_b: B. What UI layout is used?
questions.option_c: C. How is the database normalized?
questions.option_d: D. Which API endpoints are used?
questions.explanation: Identifying what tasks an actor performs helps determine related use cases that define system functionality.

questions.question: What does an Association relationship indicate in a Use Case Diagram?
questions.option_a: A. Actor participates in a use case
questions.option_b: B. One actor inherits from another
questions.option_c: C. A use case extends another
questions.explanation: An association represents communication between an actor and a use case, showing interaction flow.

questions.question: What is true about Actor Generalization?
questions.option_a: A. A child actor inherits parent behavior
questions.option_b: B. It defines associations between use cases
questions.option_c: C. Used to represent database roles
questions.explanation: Actor generalization allows a child actor to inherit all interactions and behavior from a parent actor.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes an Include relationship?
questions.option_a: A. Common behavior reused across use cases
questions.explanation: Include relationships are used when multiple use cases share common functionality that can be reused.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an Include relationship?
questions.option_a: A. Validate user in Withdraw Money use case
questions.explanation: Validation is a reusable function that can be included in various use cases such as Withdraw Money.

questions.question: Which of the following describes an Extend relationship?
questions.option_a: A. Optional behavior added to a base use case
questions.option_b: B. Mandatory step in every scenario
questions.explanation: Extend relationships add optional or conditional behavior that extends a base use case under specific conditions.

questions.question: Which is an example of an Extend relationship?
questions.option_a: A. Calculate fine if overdue in Library System
questions.explanation: An overdue fine is an optional extension that occurs only when the borrowing condition is violated.

questions.question: Which statement is true about Use Case Generalization?
questions.option_a: A. Child use case inherits parent behavior
questions.option_b: B. It defines associations between actors
questions.option_c: C. Used only in class diagrams
questions.explanation: Use case generalization represents inheritance where specialized use cases extend the behavior of a base one.

questions.question: Which is an example of Use Case Generalization?
questions.option_a: A. Make Payment → Pay via Credit Card
questions.explanation: ‘Pay via Credit Card’ is a specialized form of the general use case ‘Make Payment,’ demonstrating inheritance.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes a Use Case Scenario?
questions.option_a: A. Describes sequence of interactions for a use case instance
questions.explanation: A use case scenario narrates how an actor interacts with the system step by step in a specific situation.

questions.question: Which information is part of a Use Case Template?
questions.option_a: A. Use case ID and name
questions.explanation: Each use case is documented with a unique ID and name to identify and organize requirements efficiently.

questions.question: Which section is part of a Use Case Specification?
questions.option_a: A. Preconditions
questions.explanation: Preconditions describe the system state or requirements that must be true before executing a use case.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the Main Scenario flow?
questions.option_a: A. Steps executed when everything goes right
questions.option_d: D. Focuses on error recovery only
questions.explanation: The main scenario flow defines the normal success path of interactions between system and actor.

questions.question: Which of the following describes Extensions in a Use Case Scenario?
questions.option_a: A. Describe alternative or exceptional flows
questions.option_c: C. Always replace the main scenario
questions.explanation: Extensions handle exceptional or alternative cases that deviate from the main success flow.

questions.question: Which is a benefit of using Use Case Diagrams in Requirements Engineering?
questions.option_a: A. Easy communication with stakeholders
questions.explanation: Use case diagrams visually communicate system functionality, improving understanding among stakeholders.
